publicationStmt.authority: Centre for Computing in the Humanities, King's College London

availability.p: All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://inslib.kcl.ac.uk/

support.p: Marble stele tapering towards the top, moulded above, broken at the bottom: 0.52-0.4651.420.37. On the right and left sides are a series of graffiti in different hands; there is a relief of a horse's head on the reverse face, which is not inscribed:.

layoutDesc.layout: Inscribed on three faces. Face 1, the front face, has a at the top, columns b (left) and c (right) below it. Face 2 is to the left, Face 3 to the right.

handDesc.handNote: Face 1: Augustan. 0.015-0.02; the dedication and for homonymous patronyms, 0.03. L for ἔτους.
Faces 2 and 3: sizes varying, 0.015-0.04; intermittent E, C, W.

provenance.p: Cyrene: Agora, probably in the Square; found before 1941.

encodingDesc.p: Marked-up according to the EpiDoc Guidelines version 8

revisionDesc.change: broke provenance events into multiple provenance elements
Converted from TEI P4 (EpiDoc DTD v. 6) to P5 (EpiDoc RNG schema v. 8)

div.head: Bibliography
div.p: 7, p. 20f, figs. 13-16, whence 1962.363, and, with observations by J.M. Reynolds, SEG 20.741, , 291f., whence 1967.680; 7.

a, lines 1-17: (Jahr) 34; zur Zeit des Priesters des Apoll Isokrates des Klearchos und (des Priesters) des Imperator Caesar Sohn Gottes Augustus, Melanippos des Lysanias: die Triakatiarchen Istros (des Istros) des Agathinos, Igisan des Onomarchos, Archippos des Archippos, Eumelidas des Eumelidas, den Aporytiazon Zenion des Sosarchos, die Gymnasiarchen Apollonius des Akusagoras, Orthidas des Philokomos, Polianthes des Antimachos, und von den Presbytern Sarapion des Aristarchos . . .
On the Jewish names see Lüderitz, op.cit..
1.a.4, For the priest of Augustus at Cyrene, see nos. , . His name is used to date an inscription also in nos. , and the practice suggests that his office was annual only.
1.a.5, Cf. Eumelidas who dedicated the ephebic monument no. 652.
1.a.57 and c.13: For Jewish names see Luederitz
1.a.57, T, cf. also c., line 13 and 923 n.1; for examples of Jewish names in ephebic lists elsewhere (Koroneia in Messenia and Iasos in Caria), see Robert, line in Hellenica III, 100.
1.b.48, Probably Jewish, but perhaps rather a version of the native name transliterrated by Herodotus IV.164 as Ἀλαζειρ.
1.b.49, Probably Jewish, but perhaps rather a version of the native name transliterrated by Herodotus IV.164 as Ἀλαζειρ.
1.b.58, A man of this name was eponymous priest of Apollo in 22 B.C., see CN 39, perhaps this boy's grandfather.
2.a.12, It is possible that a Φίλων Φιλοκώμου appears as a priest of Apollo in the undated but quite early text [802] - perhaps this boy's father.
2.a.14, Perhaps to be connected with Ἥγισαν Βωλακλεῦς in the genealogy of Antionia Mego [844a, lines 18-19].
3.a.24, Possibly a son of the Βαρκαῖος Ἐτεάρχω who wrote his name on an ephabic mnument in 18 B.C., see 668b, line 1.
2.a.37: If correct, 69 of the Actian era = C.E. 38/39
